skill.name: using-skills
skill.tagline: Master Claude's skills first—your essential starting point for every conversation
skill.shortSummary: Always check for relevant skills before responding to ensure you follow Claude's established workflows and processes
skill.fullSummary: This foundational skill establishes the critical rule that you must check for applicable skills before any response or action. It prevents wasted time by ensuring you follow Claude's proven workflows rather than improvising. The skill provides clear guidelines for when and how to use skills, along with common rationalizations to avoid.

highlights.title: Mandatory Skill Check
highlights.description: You must invoke any potentially relevant skill before responding—even with just a 1% chance it applies. This check comes before clarifying questions, code exploration, or any other action. If a skill turns out to be wrong for the situation, you can simply not use it after checking.

highlights.title: Avoid Rationalization Traps
highlights.description: The skill identifies common thoughts that lead to skipping skill checks, like 'This is just a simple question' or 'I need more context first.' These rationalizations waste time and prevent you from following established workflows that would make your work more efficient and effective.

highlights.title: Clear Skill Priority
highlights.description: When multiple skills could apply, follow this order: process skills first (like brainstorming), then implementation skills (like write-plan), then verification skills (like review). This ensures you approach tasks methodically rather than jumping straight to implementation.

highlights.title: Rigid vs Flexible Skills
highlights.description: Some skills are rigid (like execute-plan) and must be followed exactly, while others are flexible (like brainstorming) where you adapt principles to context. Each skill tells you which type it is, so you know how strictly to follow it.

steps.name: Receive Request
steps.description: Get any user request, question, or task
steps.details: This could be anything from a simple question to a complex development task. The type of request doesn't matter—the skill check process applies to all conversations.

steps.name: Check Skills
steps.description: Immediately check if any skills might apply to the situation
steps.details: Use the Skill tool to check for relevant skills. Even a 1% chance a skill might apply means you should invoke it. This check happens before any response, clarification, or action.

steps.name: Follow Skill
steps.description: If a skill applies, follow its instructions directly
steps.details: The skill content will be loaded and presented to you. Follow it exactly as written. Never use the Read tool on skill files—always use the Skill tool to ensure you get the current version.

steps.name: Proceed Normally
steps.description: If no skill applies, continue with your normal response
steps.details: Only after confirming no skills apply should you proceed with clarifying questions, code exploration, or task execution. This ensures you never miss an opportunity to use established workflows.
